div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: Hall's Sanitary Washable Distemper
div.p: Made in 70 Colors
An artistic wall covering.
This celebrated water paint is made in two qualities for Inside and Outside work

HALL’S SANITARY WASHABLE DISTEMPER is rapidly superseding wall papers in all tastefully furnished homes. It is made in 70 artistic tints, and only requires the addition of water to make it ready for use. It is quickly and easily applied with a whitewash brush, with half the labour and at one third the cost of paint. HALL’S DISTEMPER ensures cleanliness, and is pleasing to the eye. It appeals alike to artistic and practical house decoration.

HALL’S DISTEMPER is of special value in hot climates. Owing to its cool, pleasing colours, great weather-resisting and germ-destroying properties, it lends itself to every kind of wall, wood, brick or stone coating, possessing all the advantages of paint, colour- wash, and disinfectant at one third the cost of oil paint. It never blisters in the hottest sun, and the fact that it can be washed adds greatly to its sanitary advantages.
Supplied in Tins and Iron Kegs.
Sole Manufacturers :
SISSONS BROTHERS & CO., LTD., HULL.
Stocks are held In Cairo by Frank Ratcliffe, Sanitary Contractor and Engineer, Sharia Saptieh.
In Alexandria by Ramadan Youssef, Sanitary Contractor, Rue Sesostris.

div.head: Thursday September 28, 1905. The Anglo-Japanese Treaty
div.p: The terms of the new treaty of friendship and alliance between England and Japan have already been foreshadowed by the "Times" but several points contained in the various articles of the treaty demand a certain amount of explanation. The treaty is in its essence defensive, guaranteeing the status quo in Eastern Asia and and important addition in India, and, while recognising the special interests of Japan in Korea is framed in a manner that should reasure those advocates of the open door who have expressed a fear that Japan, after establishing herself in the Korean Peninsula, would shut the door in the faces of her neighbors. By none has this fear been more loudly expressed than by the Americans who are themselves about to close the Philip pine Islands to foreign trade by a heavy pro tective tariff and have already closed Porto Rico and the Sandwich Islands, and who obviously fear the adoption of similar measures by the Japanese in Korea. That Japan will close Korean ports to foreign trade in defiance of her promises is as unthinkable as it is certain that most of the trade of Korea will fall to her share and that the ex ploitation of the great natural resources of the country will be mainly carried on by Japanese hands and Japanese capital. That Japan has very special advantages over her American and European trade rivals in the Far East is obvious to any one who has studied the Mongol Civilisation. Japanese literature and art had its origin in Corea and China. Buddhism possesses millions of votaries among the three great Mongol na tions and the linguistic difficulty is largely solved by the ideographic characters employed by all the three alike. Just as the Arabic figure 3 conveys the same idea to every educated European though the word is pro nounced "drei" in Germany, and "trois" in France so the Chinese ideographs represent the same idea to a reader from Tokio or Canton though they are pronounced absolutely differently. A Chinaman calls a sea "hai", a Japanese "nada" but the character which represents the idea has the same meaning to each. The Japanese trader may not be able to speak a word of Chinese but he can read the streange idogrpahs which are the despair of the Europeans. The door to trade in Korea and China may be open, but the Japanese will be the first though

The clause dealing with the eventuality of another Russo-Japanese war is obviously framed in view of the possibility of Japan attacking Russia. In that case England keeps the ring clear but should Russia attack Japan or force Japan to open hostilites by agressive action England will join her allies in the field this case clearly coming under article II of the treaty, which provides against the con tingency of any agression against the terri torial interests of either power. Then comes the Indian question. There the wording of the treaty as given by Reuter may cause a little anxiety, as the clause dealing with the question seems to forsee the possi bility of a renewal of the forward policy on the north-west frontier. That circumstances may arise which will make British interven tion in Afghanistan necessary is unfortunately possible enough, but there is alwaus a certain risk inseperable from a treaty of this sort that the Indian Government, feeling itself guaran teed by the alliances, may with the aid of sufficent expert advice enlist the support of the home Government on behalf of that for ward policy of which was once remarked that it was extremely forward but hardly politic. Otherwise the aliiance seems to us an excellent stroke on the part of a Government which, whatever its internal success, has done much for the national prestige abroad.

div.head: TERMS OF ANGLO-JAPANESE AGREEMENT. JAPAN’S RIGHT OF CONTROL IN KOREA. ENGLAND’S RIGHT TO SAFEGUARD INDIA. THE EVENT OF ANOTHER RUSSO-JAPANESE WAR
div.p: London, September 26. The text of the Anglo-Japanese agreement has been published here and at Tokio. It con- twins a preamble uni eight articles. The preamble states that the object of the agree meant is the consolidation and the maintenance of general peace in Eastern Asia and India and the preservation of the common interests of all the powers in China, by insuring the independence and integrity of that country on the principal of the open door, and the main- tenence of the territorial rights of Great Britain and Japan in Eastern Asia and India, and the defence of their special interests therein.

Article 1 stipulates that whenever the rights and interests of either party are jeopar- dised the governments shall communicate with each other fairly, and frankly consider jointly the measures to be taken to safeguard them.

Article II. provides that if by reason of an unprovoked attack or aggressive action, wher- ever arising, on the part of any power or powers either party be involved in war in defence of its territorial rights and interests, the other party will at once come to the assist- ance of its ally, and will conduct the war in common and make peace in mutual agreement.

Article III states that as Japan possesses paramount political, military, and economic rights in Korea, Great Britain recognises her right to take such measures for the guidance, control, and protection of Korea as she may deem to be a proper and necessary safeguard to advance those interests, provided that such measures do not contrary to the principle of equal commercial opportunities for all.
Article IV. states that Japan recognises the rights of Great Britain to take such measures in the proximity of the Indian frontier as may be necessary to safeguard her Indian posses- sions.
Article V. provides tint both parties agree that neither will, without consulting the other, enter into separate arrangements with another to the prejudice of the objects specified in the preamble.

Article VI. refers to the event of a Russo- Japanese war, and in such case Great Britain undertakes to maintain a strict neutrality, and to come to the assistance of Japan in the event of attack by another power.

Article VII. stipulates that the conditions under which armed assistance will be rendered shall be arranged by the Naval and Military authorities of the parties, who shall consult one another freely from time to time.
Article VIII. states that the term of the present agreement is 10 years, but it may be terminated by either party by a year’s notice to that effect. (Reuter)

London, September 26. A letter from Lord Lansdowne dated 6th inst. insructs Sir C. Hardinge to comunicate the treaty to the Russian Government, and explains that the treaty which was signed on the 12th of August has not been published hitherto with a view to the peace negotiations. He trusts that the Russian Government will recognize the fact that the new agreement is an international instrument which will be to the advantage of all powers interested in the affairs of the Far East.
Lord Lansdowne has made au identical communication to France. (Reuter)

London, September 27. Correction. Article VIII. stipulates that the agreement shall last ten years. If neither party denounce it at the end of the ninth year it will remain in force until the expiration of one year from the date upon which either has denounced it, but it will continue to be bind- ing ipso facto if either shall be engaged in war at such date of expiration. (Reuter

Paris, September 27. The signature of the Franco German agree rnent regarding Morocco has been postponed, pending the final revision. It is stated that Germany has recognised the special rights for which France has contended. (Reuter

div.head: AUSTRIA AND HUNGARY
div.p: Budapest, September 27. The Emperor’s refusal to listen to any changes in the Hungarian army has united all parties in Hungary against the Crown. The leaders of the coalition have issued a manifesto denouncing the Soverign’s attempt to cripple the nation's control over its own affairs. (R.)

div.head: DISASTROUS TYPHOON AT MANILA
div.p: Manila, September 27. A typhoon here has killed 10 natives and wounded 500. A thousand are homeless, and damage to the extent of £100,000 has been done. (Reuter

div.head: A SECOND PEACH CONFERENCE
div.p: St. Petersburg, September 27. Russia has invited the Powers to another conference at the Hagna. (Havas

div.head: H.H. THE KHEDIVE. KHEDIVE’S VISIT TO CONSTANTINOPLE
div.p: Constantinople September 27. H.H. the Khedive is leaving Constantinople with his mother, expressed his satisfaction at the warm reception extended to him by the Sultan. (Havas)

div.head: ARRIVAL AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The steamer Dalmatia which had been chartered by H.H. the Khedive for his journey from Constantinople to Alexandria arrived at 2 a.m. this morning. A guard of honor com- posed of the Quay Police had been stationed all night at the harbour to keep order and paraded as soos as the approach of the Dal- matia was signalled. The Government offices and steamers in the harbour flew the Egyptian flag. At 6 am. a special launch conveyed the Khodive to Ras el Tin palace, where the Mi- nisters, the Governor of Alexandria, and the Princes of the Khedivial family awaited his arrival. As he stopped on shore a salute of 21 guns greeted his return to Egyptian soil and the Princes and Ministers hastened to pay the courtesias and utter the greetings usual on such occasions. At 7.40 a.m. the Khedivah and the young princes and princesses with a large suite left for the Montazah Palace, H.H. the Khedive remaining for the time at Ros et Tin.

div.head: NORTH EGYPT LAND COMPANY LIMITED
div.p: We are authorized by the Board of Di- rectors in London to state that this Company has completed the whole of the preliminaries and that all the preparatory work is now a "fait accompli”. The London Directors are making arrangements for the payments to be made in order to complete the acquisition of the pro- perties purchased from the Daira Khassa of H. H. the Khedive and the measuring of the lands and the preparation of the first season’s cultivation is being proceeded with at once.

This well known agricultural engineer, M. N. Alchevsky, has just left London for Alexandria for the special object of putting the work in hand as set out in the reports of Sir Douglas Fox and Partners.

We understand that the support of a vary important and influential group in Paris has been obtained, and that this group has taken a large interest in the Company and that we shall shortly see the shares quoted on the Paris Bourse as well as on the London Stock Exchange.

We have it on the same authority that the Daira Khassa of H.H. the Khedive has obtain- ed the nomination of its representative on the Board of the Company in consequence of the large interest which the Daira Khassa has secured in the Company.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION
div.p: Official intimation has been received at Cairo and Khartoum from the War Office in London that in future the British troops sta- tioned at the latter place will be under the command and immediate orders of the Sirdar and Governor General of the Sudan and not as hitherto of the General officer commanding in Egypt. This change has been decided upon on the recommendation of Sir Reginald Wingate and with the entire concurrence and approval of Lord Cromer.

The statement published on Tuesday by a Cairo contemporary that it is intended to gradually augment the British garrison of the Suiluu as that country develops and its trade improves, is incorrect. We learn from the highest authority that the recent decision of the house authorities to maintain the force stationed in this country at its present strength will be strictly adhered to and in future one infantry regiment and a detachment of the Royal Army Medics Corps will, as heretofore, be quartered at Khartoum.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Tuscan Prince, from Manchester, left Malta yesterday with passengers and general cargo and is duo to arrive at Alex- andria on Sunday.
The Mosa line Maeris sailed from Glasgow yesterday morning and is due at Alexandria on the 12th October.
The Messageries, Maritimes road boat Portu- gal, which left Alexandria last Friday, arrived at Marreilles yesterday morning.

The Russian Steam Navigation Company’s mail boat Tehatchoff will leave Alexandria on Wednesday next for Odessa, calling at Piaens, Snyrna, the Dardanel’es, and con- necting with the same companies mail boats for Sevastapool, the Anatolian, Carasian, Crimean and Sea of Arov ports.

div.head: All Saint’s Church, Cairo
div.p: On and after Sunday next October 1 the Holy Communion will be celebrated at All Saint’s Church, Cairo at 8.30 a.m. instead of at 8 and the morning service will begin at 10.30 a.m instead of at 9.30.

div.head: Church of Scotland Schools
div.p: Two new teachers have been appointed to reinforce the staff of the Scottish Schools. Mr. Wm. Thom from Aberdeen has already arrived and Mr. Maurice Goodrick from Great Yarmouth will arrivo early in October. Fall particulars will be seen in our advertisement in another column.

div.head: Port Sudan
div.p: A special commission will assemble during November to consider the various matters in connection with the disposal and allotment of land for building purposes at Port Sudan. The recommendations of the commission will afterwards be submitted to the Governor General at Khartoum for his final decision.

div.head: San Stefano Casino
div.p: The charity performance to be held at the San Stefano Casino to-morrow afternoon in aid of the Calabrian sufferers promisee to be most brilliant. The organisers. H E. Khalil Hamdi Pasha Hamada and the San Stefano Club are doing their utmost to provide an excellent programme and to judge from the items, which we published yesterday, their efforts will meet with great success.

div.head: Suicide of an Officer
div.p: Ahmed Effeudi Khoury, an officer of the 10th battalion. Egyp- tian Army, died on Monday from a self-inflicted bullet wound in the abdomen. He left a letter to his mother leaving her all his money after payment of hi*s outstanding debts. The occur- ence was rendered more tragic by the fact that the deceased officer was about to be married. Tho motive for the act is absolutely unknown.

div.head: To aid the Calabrians
div.p: A special news- paper will be published on Sunday by the International Society for tho Help of Persons Suffering from Accidents,appealing to the residents of this town to give generously to the relief fund for the victims of the Calabrian earthquake. The appeal will be made in five different languages, Arabic, English, French Italian, and Greek, and this publication will, we imagine, be unique.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Bank
div.p: We are informed that the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd., will open an Agency at Mansourah on October 2. The officers of the new agency are situated in the main street quite close to the rail- way station. BP's will be discounted and foreign exchange given, in fact banking business of all sorts will be carried on by the branch, the establishment of which is welcomed by the inhabitants of Mansourah and the neighbourhood. Mr. C. E. Green will manage the now agency.

div.head: New Military Buildings in Cairo
div.p: A confrere stated recently that the War Office proposed to dispose of the military school and the barracks behind it at Abbassiah and the adjoining land and with the proceeds of the sale to erect now new buildings beyond tho Polygon. Tho true facts of the case are that the military authorities have decided upon building a new school and barracks for the infantry battalions stationed at Abbassieh, as they consider the present old buildings not worth repairing, but they are awaiting the necessary grant from the Ministry of Finance who will then dispose of the present buildings as it deems best.

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce
div.p: We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer- chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appoint- ing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual subscription is merely the nominal one of £1. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquirers can obtain farther particulars from our London office, 36, New Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: THE CHATHAM EXPLOSION. SUCCESSFULLY PERFORMED. STATE TELEGRAPHS BREAK DOWN. (From our Correspondent.)
div.p: (By Telegraph). Port Said, Thursday 8.48 a.m. Mr. Harris and his assistants commenced fixing the firing charger in the holds of the Chatham at six o'clock this morning and it a expect that all will be ready for the explosion by nine o’clock. The "all ready’ signal, how- ever, has not yet been given though it is ex- pected at any moment and excited crowds are watching the offices of the Suer Canal Com- pany. The state telegraph lines have not been out as it is hoped that they may escape damage. A large number of special correspon- dents, representing both the Egyptian and foreign Press, left for Ras el Esh by special train at eight o’clock.

The explosion of the Chatham took place at 9.58 a.m. I took up my position on the roof of the Eastern Exchange Hotel as being the most suitable site, from which to view the explosion and that I might be able to wire you the result without delay. I am, therefore, unable to go into details but will wire you fully at the earliest possible moment.

The great event has passed successfully but I cannot say to what extent the mari- time and fresh water canals have been dam- aged. The lines of the State Telegraphs have been broken and messages are being sent via the cable of theEastern Telegraph Company.

As for the explosion, from my position it appeared as if a vast colnmn of grey smoke, shaped like a gigantic tree, was rushing up- wards with great rapidity. No earth tremor was perceptible and the surface of the water in the harbour and in the canal all along the stretch visible from here was not disturbed in the slightest degree.

Had we not been waiting in feverish excite- ment and expecting one knew not what, the explosion would have in all probability passed unnoticed. The tradesmen, of the town, who had closed their shops in many instances, were greatly surprised, as were indeed all those who had remained in Port Said, and perhaps a little disappointed that some damage was not done to a few windows.
A telegram has just been received from lamailia stating that shortly before 10 a.m. the sound of the explosion was very distictly heard at lamailia 25 miles from Ras-el-Esh.

div.head: STOP PRESS EDITION (By Telegraph).
div.p: Port Said 1.36 p.m. The explosion has been a great success. The fore part of the ship has been blown away as far as the fore engine room. There are now twenty-two metres of water underneath the explosive magazine. The canal is now only five metres deep in the middle, the average depth of water having been nice metres before explosion. The charge was fired from kilometre 12 by Mr. Harris. Seven observers were watching from this point, the remainder waiting at kilometer 8. Fearful damage was done to the Asiatic shore, a ritt 50 feet long being blown in the east bunk. No damage was done to the African back. The rails have not been disturbed. The Canal telegraph wires have been destroy- ed. The State wires will be repaired by 3 p.m. The fresh water canal is uninjured. Showers of debris fa11 in the circle of 600 yards radius, Beams, rails, fragments of the engines, and plates were hurled everywhere. Thousands of fish were killed. Repair gangs are on the spot It is hoped that the dual will be dear in seven days.

To-day’s operations at kilometre 19 were, from all I hear, decidedly interesting. Mr. Harris in company with his assistants and the chief electrician of the Canal Company were to be been at the railway station at an early hour making enquiries fur special materials which had been rent from Alexandria. The party, after having procured some special instruments for testing electric currents from the electric light station, proceeded to the Canal office where Mr. Tillier held a short consulta- tion with Mr. Harris, after which, he and his party proceeded in the Albatross down the canal and took with them cables, wires, and a quantity of other material for the tests which it was proposed to carry through to-day. The party arrived at Ras el Esh where a gang was awaiting the arrival of the explosives train which had attached to it a powder waggon holding twenty oases of high explosives, all of exactly the same type ad is to be found in the bold of the unfortunate Chatham, viz red dynamite and blasting gelatine. In the waggon were also rolls of new submarine cable and a considerable quantity of other necessary mater- ial for the monster explosion.

The experts then proceeded to test the wires and batteries, of which there were severed, the principal being a twist exploder of the very latest type with which quite a number marine detonators were fired.Test followed test; long and short cables in fact every imaginable trial was made, many of a most severe character, the idea being that there should not be the slightest chance of any hitch occurring on Thursday. I understand that after some hours of these trials of every possible combination, Mr. Harris declared himself satisfied in everv way. and he is un- doubtedly of the opinion that things will go smoothly at the proper time. The power of this twist exploder is stupendous, registering a number of empires such as is not indicated on the newest and beat devised of voltameter- which Mr. Harris used in his trials. The voltage also is large but, from what I know of the matter, I believe that it is not voltage - which is of such paramount importance but volume, which quality is only indicated by the number of amperes a battery registers when actually delivering its electric force. The detonators to be used in the explosion are of the most recent manufacture and are construct- ed purely and simply for submarine work. The detonating charge is enclosed within a brass tube, which in its turn is covered with thick layers of guttapercha and tape. The firing shock is delivered along two copper wires which terminate in the interior of the fuse in a small platino-iridium bridge. The action of these fuses is simple ; the current of sui- able volume being delivered along the wires from the battery heats the bridge in a moment, the bridge at once glows, and, in so doing, fires the charge of fulminate of mercury contained in the brass tube. This shook being commun- icated to the mine in which the fuse is placed, causes the material of the mine to explode. After firing quite a number of detonators the party returned to the Ras el Esh station and eventually arrived at Port Said at a late hour.

The explosives which arrived at kilometre 14 at about 2 p.m. were carefully transported across the canal to the Asiatio bank and there covered up and left properly guarded. They will remain there until to morrow, when Mr. Harris proposes to prepare the mines for the great event.

The Canal Company’s steam launch was early at work again to-day taking M. Tillier, the Chef da Transit, and Mr. Harris’ party down the canal, so that they might make all final arrangements, and prepare the firing charges before dark, for to-morrow morning. During the day the telegraph staff were- busy clearing all the wires which are to be used to-morrow and n umbers of men were putting the final touches to the other prepara- tions, notably those connected with the fresh water canal and railway.

A considerable number of rails have been accumulated at kilometres 14 and 24 in readiness to proceed at once with the repairs which may be necessary after the explosion, and gangs of railway men were being instruct- ed in their duties so that there might be as little delay as possible when the time comes for action.

Mr. Harris and his staff prooceeded to the wreak early in the morning and passed a final inspection, making several slight modi- fications in the arrangements with a view to having things straight and clear before the fixing of the mines took place.

Ten cases of explosives were handled, their contents being emptied into canvas bags which were made on the spot and were afterwards sown up. There are two mines; the larger one of 3001bs. of blasting gelatine and dynamite is intended for the magazine of the vessel, and the smaller charge, mode np in exactly the same way of 200 lbs. of similar material, is to go into No. 3 hold.

The wires being made and the detonator having been connected to their respective charges, tea wires which are to traverse the canal from the telephone cables on the west bank, were attached and the joints most care- fully made. After this a length of cable equal to the distance between the two holds was connected to the charges and all was declared ready.
The wires were stowed away and locked up on board a dahabesh ; the batteries were ins- pected ; and the party returned to Port Said after a most tiring day.

At 5 am. to-morrow the launch will leave Port Said with Mr. Harris and party and several of the Canal Company’s chiefs. It will then proceed at once to place the mines, and make final connections aided by divers and a large staff of telegraph line workers in charge of Mr. Plum. The detachment of sol- diers will take up their positions at five kilo- metres radius from the wreck. The police will form a cordon at Rasowa to prevent an exodus of Port Said residents. No one will be allowed to go to Ras el Esh except officials of the Canal Company. All the wires are to be cut on Wednesday night and Mr. Harris expects to have all ready by 7.30 a.m.
All messages will be conveyed from and to officials stationed at different points by mount- ed men.

At 8 a.m. a signal will be hoisted on the flagstaff of the Canal Company's offices. At 9 a.m. the current will be closed and the greatest explosion of dynamite which the world has ever known will take place, Mr. Harris firing the battery at Bas el Esh. The folowing will be stationed at the generative stations—
M, M. Tillier, Doyen, Rsynaud, Smith, Percier, Jusserand, Coulloun, Lord Ed. Cecil, and six or seven other offinals, Mr. Harris and assistants.
No one else wUl be allowed there, but a few photographers will be permitted to «‘ation themselves at kilometre 13.6.

div.head: ESBEKIAH GARDENS.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut-Colonel R.Q.C. Cox commanding, and officers, 2nd Royal In- nsakilling Fusiliers, the Band will play the following programme of music by quasi request in the Esbekieh Gardens tomorrow (Friday) evening, commencing at 9 am.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lady Cromer does not retain to Cairo with the Earl of Cromer next month, but will come out in November.
Sir Rudolf von Slatin Pasha is expected to arrive on Monday next by the Austrian Lloyd mail boat.

A b suite de cetto requête et d conclusions qui y sont proposées, le Tribunal rendu l’ordonn.vice dont voioi lo texte :

" Noos Tuck, jngc-comnmsaire ; ^"Vais requête qui précède et les f vite exporés ; va notre ordonnance en date du ! eptembro 1905; disons, «i co qui concerne coatiôlo institué par notre susdite ordonnanc que celui-ci s’exercera par b signature de dec drs trois oontiôleurs désignés, disons que l’a torisation de continner son commerce impliqi pour la Société Générale des Sucreries et de Raffinerie d’Egypte, le droit de oontiunor, au diligences de son administrateur délégué, 5 Arthur J. Davey, ees relatious habitnelles avt l’Anglo Egyptian Bank, consistant notammei dans le retrait des sucres bruts gagés k b dit Banque ot leur remplacement on natore on e espèces, à cet effet signer tous documents que conques et prendre tous engagements découlai da contrat existant entre bdite Banque et 1 e Société."

Rien n’est encore décidé au sujet d troisième oxpert. Nous apprenons sêalemen que M. Vaast & écrit au président du Tribum l’informaut que son Conseil d’administratio l’autorisait k remplir la mission d’expert a cas ou il en serait chargé.
liarari pacha est arrivé avant-hier an Caii ot a ou hier matin nne première entrevu avec MM. Davey et Naus. MM. Leroux, de 1 Bonglise, Poutre!, Mo Pangalo et M. Nine assistaient à cotte réunion.
La nouvelle administration élabore en o moment un plan de réformes tendant à intre dnire de sérieuses économies dans l'adminis tration des Sucreries.

div.head: UPPER NILE PROBLEMS. BY SIR WILLIAM GARSTIN.
div.p: Sir William Garstin writes in the “Nineteenth Century and After” as follows :— Recent years - more particularly those sub- sequent to the reconquest of the Sudan—have been productive of a large amount of literature descriptive of the Nile, so large in fact that it might fairly be assumed that the subject had been exhausted.

I myself must plead guilty to having contri- buted no inconsiderable share to the existing mass of writing, and I feel much hesita- tion about still further adding to it. I am, moreover, only too well aware that anyone who may read the present article— under the supposition that it contains some- thing new—will speedily dieoover that aooh is not the case. It has, however, been pointed out to me that all my previous notes upon the Nile have appeared in the shape of Bluebooks, or other official documents, and have conse- quently not come in the way of the general reader. Also that, having been purely technical reports, they have necessarily been unattract- ive to many people.

The last fact is doubtless true, but I confess to finding some difficulty in presenting the subject in any but a technical form, or in other than technical language. I shall probably fail to make my meaning dear, bat I will ne- vertheless make the attempt, in the hope that a short account of the schemes proposed for controlling the river may be of some interest to those who take a pride in following the progress of England’s work in Egypt and the Sudan.

It is, I fear, inevitable that I should commerce with a subject now worn well-sigh threadbare : namely, a brief description of the great stream to which Egypt owes its being. I will, however, make this portion of my article as short as possible, and will devote the greater part of space allotted to explaining what are the projects by which it is proposed to obtain a control over the waters of the Nile, from its sources to the sea.

To most people, the bewildering nomencla- ture of this river, throughout its course, must form a serious obstacle to their comprehension of any general description. Who, for instance- is to understand that the Victoria Nile, the Bahr-el Gebel, the Bahr-al Zaraf, and the White Nile, are all one and the same river ? It would be infinitely simpler were the whole stream, from its outlet at Lake Victoria to its junction with the Blue Nile at Khaitoum, to be called by its best known name—the White Nile. Such a change would certainly be to the advantage of the general reader as well as of the geo- grapher and the map maker.

It is, of course, unnecessary to do more than mention the fact that the Nile, north of Khartoum, is formed by the j auction of two important waterways—the Blue Nile, flawing from the south-east, and the White Nile, coming from the west, or rather from the. far south. Both there rivers have their origin in lakes of large sire, situated upon plateaux of considerable altitude above the sea. Most people are aware that the source of the Blue Nile is in Lake Tsana, in the northern table- land of Abyssinia, and that of the White Nile in the Victoria Nyanza—that vast fresh-water sea which lies under the equator, in the uplands of Uganda. The volume of the White Nile is further augmented by the waters of two lakes, in the same region —namely, the Albert Edward and the Albeit Nyanzas. From the north end of the last-named lake it issues as the river which conveys to Egypt the united waters of the three equatorial reservoirs. The two great streams which together form the Nile at Khartoum differ in their character to an extreme degree, but both play important parts in producing the remarkable regularity of its annual rise and fall. There can, however, be no question that the White Nile is the parent river, and that its constancy of supply alone renders existence possible in the countries which border its northern valley. The Abyssi- nian stream, although providing the rich muddy floods which bring fertility to the lands of Egypt, has but a fitful existence, and its waters fail altogether at the moment when most required, and when, for want of their .refresh- ing assistance, the thirsty laud lies parched and baked under the scorching rays of the African summer son.

A few words mast suffice to describe the essential differences between these two rivers. The Blue Nile dashes down from the Abys- sinian highlands, traversing a wild and beauti- ful country, for the most part a land of forest- clad mountains and of torrential streams. Its valley runs in a deep cleft or gash, several thousand feet below the general surface level, and no explorer has as yet succeeded in follow- ing it throughout its length. Through this canyon the Blue Nile rashes, from time to time dropping over a succession of falls, with a very heavy slope and a rocky bed. It is not until some half of its course has been run that it issues into comparatively open country. Even here its stream is rapid, its banks are high and densely wooded, and tbs difference between its maximum and minimum water- levels is excessive. The volume of this river is supplemented by that of numerous tri- butaries, most of them turbulent torrents like itself, and all of thorn draining the western face of the Abyssinian plateau.

The waters of the Blue Nile, when this river is low, are of crystalline clearness and lim pidity. At such periods they are remarkable for the brilliant blue colour by which they reflect the sky. With the advent of the floor they become heavily charged with sediment the scourings of the volcanic rocks and the leaf-mould of the forest land through which the Blue Nile passes. At this season, their colour resembles that of coffee lees. It is to the deposit which they contain that Egypt owes the productiveness for which its lands have been renowned from the earliest times. The difference between the volume) of the Blue Nile when in flood, and when its waters have shrunk to their lowest limits, is very great—the former being from sixty to seventy time as great as the latter.
The White Nile is, in all respects, a striking contrast to its great eastern sitter.

In the upper portions of its coarse, it too travers a country remarkable for the romantic beauty and the varied character of its lands capes. The sources of the chief southern feeder of Lake Victoria—the Kagera river—lie in a sterile and lava-covered regions, out of which rise the jagged peaks of a chain of volcanoes, some of which are still active, This land is at most seasons shrouded in a smoky huts, and the entire area is honeycombed by the inverted cones of long extinct craters. Dreary and in- hospitable as is this portion of the Nile scenery, in the neighbourhood of the lakes more pleasing conditions prevail The Victoria Nyanza is studded by numerous islands of picturesque shape, their outline softened by j masses of indescribably beautiful vegetation. These green elevations are mirrored in the calm water, and contrast exquisitely with the everchanging lights and the opalescent tints of its surface. The scene of the Albert Edward and Albert lakes differs com pletely from that of Like Victoria. Around these lonely sheets of water the landscape is desolate and gloomy, as the mountains hem in their shores on every side. Even here, how- ever, the scene presents a series of pictures, characterised by a wild and savage grandeur. Above the plateau which separates the two lake systems towers the noble mass of Reunzori —the legendary Mountains of the Moon—its loftier summits clothed with a mantle of perpetual snow, and apparently piercing the clouds which cap them.

The intervening tableland consists of rolling expanses of woodland, alternating with open but undulating country. The low rounded hills are carpeted with a verdure of extraordinary luxuriance— numerous wild flowers, of large size and brilliant colours, giving it the aspect of a giant’s garden. The hollows are some- times filled by groves of magnificent trees, and sometimes by swamps, clothed by the sombre- looking papyrus The river channel connecting the different lakes occasionally traverses open and grassy plains—the home of numerous antelopes—but more often passes through rock gorger and deep valleys, which lie swelter- ing, throughout the year, in a damp tropical heat, and which are shrouded by an im- penetrable growth of large trees, tang'ed snake-like creepers and dense underwood. The recesses of these primeval forests have, as yet, been hardly penetrated by any living thing, except by the strange animals, and the still stranger types of human beings, which find a sanctuary within their leafy shelter.

After issuing from the Albert lake, the Nile tears over a series of picturesquely beautiful falls and rapids, or glides with a swift current between bush clad hills, which again are bounded by lofty mountain ranges, demarcating its valley like a wall. Down the ravines, numerous torrents leap, in s succession of cascades, into the main stream.

Such natural beauties, however, are only to be met with in a comparatively small portion of the valley of the White Nile. After about one quarter of its total length has been accomplished, this rivers enters the Und of the great marshes, and from this point its character abruptly and entirely changes The rocky bed, the heavy slope, and the tumbling, sparkling water disappear, and are replaced by a muddy bottom, a low velocity, and a stream flowing in a wide and shallow channel, between low reed-covered banks, and intersected by numerous swampy islands. For many hundred miles it pursues a tortuous course through wide marshes, losing much of its slope, by by reason of the endless loops and bends which succeed one another with maddening regularity. The colour of its water too changes completely, and assumes a brownish green hue. In this region the Nile passes through those swamps in which occur the sudd blocks, those remarkable weed barriers which have, in the past, completely barred its flow, and which have only, writhing the last few years, been removed by the efforts of a small band of Eng- lish officers. This melancholy-looking expanse stretches like a ready ocean in all directions, and covers an area of several thousand square miles—for the most part, a horrible marsh, filled 'by tall reeds and papyrus, and well described by the late Sir Samuel Baker as “a heaven for mosquitoes and a damp hell for men.” The dead flat horizon is rarely broken by any elevation, and the sight of even an occa- sional bush, or stunted tree, is welcome as relieving, in some small degree, the prevailing monotony of the hideous landscape. These swamps are interspersed by shallow lagoons— some of considerable size—which are filled by water spilling into them from the river channel It is to the evaporation on there lagoons, end to the absorption of the water plants, this tire- great waste of water on the White Nile is chiefly due. So great, indeed, is the regulating affect of three marshes that, at the point where the Bahr-el-Gebel finally issues from the sudd country, it has lost from 50 to 85 per cent of the volume which it brought down from the hills, and the quantity which it discharge* into -he White Nile varies bat little throughout the year. This appalling loss of water,is one of the most remarkable features characterising the White Nils, or, as it is called in its course through the swamps, the Bahr-el-GebeL. No matter how high may be the water-level of Lake Albert, or bow large the added yolume brought in by the tributary streams which enter the river, the discharge of the Nils at the point where it issues from the sudd area is practically constant at all seasons and under all conditions.
The prevention of this loss of water is the chief problem connected with the Nile which requires solution.

Apart from the numerous torrents which feed the Bahr-el-Gebel in its tempestuous course through the hills, this river, or rather that portion of it known it the White Nile, recedes the waters of two main affluents—one coming from the west and one from the east These are both perennial streams, but differ largely from each other in their effect upon the flow of the main river. The western tri- butary is known as the Bahr-el-Ghazal, or Gaulle river. It drains the north eastern pla- teau of the watershed between the Nile and the Congo. It is fed by numerous streams, but, in the last two hundred mile* of its course, it traverses a series of immense marshes, in watch it loses its entire slope, and in which its waters are sucked up as by a sponge. So much is this the case that the Bahr-el-Ghazal, where it enters the Nile, is little more than a deep and reedy ditch, of almost stagnant water, playing no part whatever in the system of supply, beyond perhaps that of a reservoir, from which the water, not evaporated in the swamps, filters down into the White Nile, when the levels of this last are low enough to permit of its doing so.

The eastern tributary of the White Nile— the Subat—plays a very different role from the Bahr-el-Ghazal, and, indeed, it is upon the dit- charge of this river that, for some months of the year. Egypt depends for the greater portion of its water supply. The Sobat is a true moun tain stream rising in the southern Abyssinian plateau. At certain periods its waters shrink to a very insignificant amount, and its bed is almost dry. For nearly half the year it comes down in a heavy flood, and, when fall, the volume which it adds to the White Nile is nearly three times as great as that brought down from the equatorial lakes by the medium of the Bahr-el-Gebel. It is to the cloudy milk- white colour imparted by the Sobat water that the White Nile owes its name.

Before I discuss the different projects for controlling the Upper Nile, I must say a few words regarding the parts respectively played by the lake reservoirs and by the several rivers which combine to form the great system of which the Nile is composed.

Such remarks must of necessity be very brief, as anything like a detailed description of this intricate question would far exceed the limits of an article like the present Moreover, the information available is still sadly limited, and only covers a very short period of time. Each succeeding year, however, adds to our know- ledge, and enables us to understand better how complex -but how perfect—is the system which creates this great river. As regards the lakes which form its sources, all recent infor- mation tends to prove that the potentiality of these natural reservoirs, as regards water storage, is less than had formerly been imagined, and that the annual rise and fall of their levels is chiefly determined by the rainfall, and by the evaporation on their sur- faces, rather than by the water added by the rivers of their catchment areas, or withdrawn by the Nile itself.

Thus, Lake Teana—the source of the Blue Nile—does not appear to affect materially the discharge of that river, or to be seriously affected itself, as regards its level, by the amount of water drawn off it by the Nile at any season of the year. The volume which passes the outlet appears to be altogether insignificant, and, even when the lake is full, would seem to be as nothing compared with that added by the drainage of the Blue Nile valley, or by its great tributaries, the Dabus, the Dudeesa, the Rahad, and the Dinder.

Turning to the White Nile although it is beyond question that its true source is the Victoria Nyanza, it now seems almost certain that—owing to the effect of the man has of the Choga lake, through which the river passes after leaving tire Ripon fells—the volume of water issuing from Lake Victoria is so regulat- ed and reduced that the quantity which event- ually reaches the Albert Nyanza is practically constant throughout the year, however high or low the levels of the latter lake may be. Consequently, the part which the Victoria Nyanza plays, with regard to the Nile dis- charge, is limited to passing a constant (apply into the Albert lake. I do not mean to assert that the volume which reaches Lake Albert by means of the connecting river—the Victoria Nile - is a constant one, but oily that portion of it which is due to the Victoria lake. North of Lake Choga, the rainfall in the Nile valley is very heavy, and at times largely increases the volume which enters the Albert Nyanza.

With this last named lake the case is vary different, and upon the levels of its waters the supply of the White Nile largely depends. If Lake Victoria is the tree source. Lake Albert is the true reservoir of the Nila, and, to soma extant, the regulator which determines the volume which passes down the river. Allusion has already been mad* to the fact that the Albert Nyanza receives the waters of both lake systems—namely, that of the Victo- ria Nile, and that of the Albert Edward, by the medium of the Semliki river. This last stream is supplied not alone by Lake Albert Edward, but also by the melting snows, and the glaciers of the Ruenzori mountains.

The Uganda plateau has two periods of annual rainfall, the one from March to June, and the other from October to January. The periods of maximum and minimum supply in the lakes differ considerably, as Lake Victoria is at its highest by the end of May, and at its lowest in September. The Albert lake' rises steadily throughout the summer, but does not reach its maximum until November or December, and, as a rule, its minimum by the end of March. It is the sustained rise, throughout the rammer months, which renders this lake so suitable as a possible storage reservoir.

The rainfall in the Upper Nile valley itself is heavy in the late autumn, and again in July and August. This fills the tributary torrents which enter the Upper Nile below its outlet from the lake. As Lake Albert fells, and thus torrents dry ip, the Nile fells too, and reaches its minimum in March or April. The lake than begins to rise again, and the heavy rainfall of July and August again bring* Urge flashes into the Nile, by means of its tributaries, and the river attains its maximum in September. The affect of three tributaries, however, is much less im- portant that that of lake Albert, and all the latest information collected goes to show that the level of this reservoir is the decid- ing factor of the river discharge, the torrents playing only a secondary part If, then, the lake levels, at the end of the year, are high, the supply in the Bahr-el-Gebel in the following summer will almost certainly be a good one, and the flood most probably a high one. If, on the contrary, the lake levels in December are low, thee, no matter how much water is brought in by the tributary rivers, the summer supply in the following year will be below the average, and the flood most probably a poor one. I wish to lay special stress upon this point, as it is in connection with lake Albert that the solution of the problem of securing a permanent summer supply for the Nile is to be found. It is, of course, understood that when I talk about the flood in the Nile being a good one, or the reverse, I only allude to the amount of water reaching the great swamps. If my description of the Upper Nile has been in any way intelligible, it will have been understood that, from the time it reaches the marshes, this river become, to all intents and purposes, a lost one.

With the foregoing information before us, it is possible to comprehend the part played by the different rivers, which together form tire Nile, throughout a year of average supply, During the months of April and May all these are at their lowest, and, practically, the only water passing Khartoum is that which comes through the White Nile marshes,supple- mented by a very small volume brought down by the Blue Nile, la Jane the Abyssinian rainfall causes the eastern river to rise more or less steadily. The flood increases rapidly in July and attains its maximum in August, falling quickly in September. The Atbara— another important tributary of the Nile— begins to rise in June and is in fall flood in August, but generally a little in advance of the Blue Nile. It, too, fells rapidly in Sept- ember, and is dry during the winter months. Meanwhile, on the White Nile, as has been already demonstrated, a constant but small discharge, derived from the equatorial lakes, issues from the great marches by means of Bahr-el-Gebel and its loop, the Bahr-el-Zaraf. The flood rise in the White Nile is conse- quently entirely dependent upon the the volume of the Sobat. This river, in an average year, begins to bring in water to the main stream in the month of June, and after this date its discharge increases rapidly, attaining its maximum in September or Octo- ber, after which it falls rapidly. As the vol- ume added to the Nile by the Sobat in- creases, the water in the former river—above the junction - is held back, and ponded up. The marshes are that flooded for a consi- derable distance up stream, and form a re- servoir which cannot discharge itself until the Sobat flood has passed away. Meanwhile the Sobat water passes to the north, down the White Nile channel, taking the place of the lake water, and from July until Octo- ber practically forms the entire supply which reaches Khartoum by the medium of the White Nile.
